body:
Some more results...:

PS H:\> (Get-Date '01-01-1970 00:00:00Z')
donderdag 1 januari 1970 01:00:00
_as expected. Automatically converted to local time, being in CET = UTC+1_

PS H:\> (Get-Date '01-01-1970 00:00:00Z').ToLocalTime()
donderdag 1 januari 1970 01:00:00
_as expected. Automatically converted to local time, being in CEST = UTC+1, manually converted to local time, staying the same_

PS H:\> (Get-Date '01-07-1970 00:00:00Z')
woensdag 1 juli 1970 02:00:00
_exactly 181 days after '01-01-1970 00:00:00Z'_
_as expected. Automatically converted to local time, being in CEST = CET+DST = UTC+2_

PS H:\> (Get-Date '01-07-1970 00:00:00Z').ToLocalTime()
woensdag 1 juli 1970 02:00:00
_exactly 181 days after '01-01-1970 00:00:00Z'_
_as expected. Automatically converted to local time, being in CEST = CET+DST = UTC+2, manually converted to local time, staying the same_

PS H:\> (Get-Date '01-01-1970 00:00:00Z').AddSeconds(15638400)
woensdag 1 juli 1970 01:00:00
NOT as expected. Being exactly 181 days after '01-01-1970 00:00:00Z'_, but in CEST now. Should be as above.

PS H:\> (Get-Date '01-01-1970 00:00:00Z').AddSeconds(15638400).ToLocalTime()
woensdag 1 juli 1970 01:00:00
NOT as expected. Being exactly 181 days after '01-01-1970 00:00:00Z'_, but in CEST now. Should be as above.

(15638400 seconds = 181 days)
Just to be sure...:  

PS H:\> Get-TimeZone
Id                         : W. Europe Standard Time
DisplayName                : (UTC+01:00) Amsterdam, Berlin, Bern, Rome, Stockholm, Vienna
StandardName               : W. Europe Standard Time
DaylightName               : W. Europe Summer Time
BaseUtcOffset              : 01:00:00
SupportsDaylightSavingTime : True

Looking into this, a problem is that being in UTC+1 leads to deceptive examples (I'm running in UTC-8).

These actual behaviours are in .NET rather than in PowerShell.

```
> ([datetime]'01-01-2018 00:00:00')

Monday, January 1, 2018 12:00:00 AM

```

```
> ([datetime]'01-01-2018 00:00:00').AddSeconds(15638400)

Sunday, July 1, 2018 12:00:00 AM

```

```
> ([datetime]'01-01-2018 00:00:00').AddSeconds(15638400).ToLocalTime()

Saturday, June 30, 2018 5:00:00 PM

```

The part to watch here is the [`Kind`](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/system.datetime.kind?view=netcore-2.2):

```
> (Get-Date '01-01-2018 00:00:00').Kind
Unspecified

> ([datetime]'01-01-2018 00:00:00').Kind
Unspecified

> (Get-Date '01-01-2018 00:00:00Z').Kind
Local

> ([datetime]'01-01-2018 00:00:00Z').Kind
Local
```

It looks like a `DateTime` value will retain its kind and will behave and be displayed appropriately. `Unspecified` seems to behave the same as `Utc`, but I think the distinction exists to record that the timezone was not explicitly given.

When a `Local` time is not DST, it **will not be converted to DST** when time is added. It keeps its original timezone (where the DST timezone is treated as distinct from the standard one). But when `ToLocalTime()` is used, it converts the time to the appropriate geographically local timezone that applies *at the time of the datetime value*:

```
> ([datetime]'01-01-2018 00:00:00')

Monday, January 1, 2018 12:00:00 AM

> ([datetime]'01-01-2018 00:00:00').ToLocalTime()

Sunday, December 31, 2017 4:00:00 PM

> ([datetime]'01-01-2018 00:00:00').AddSeconds(15638400)
                                                                     
Sunday, July 1, 2018 12:00:00 AM

> ([datetime]'01-01-2018 00:00:00').AddSeconds(15638400).ToLocalTime()

Saturday, June 30, 2018 5:00:00 PM

> ([datetime]'01-01-2018 00:00:00Z')

Sunday, December 31, 2017 4:00:00 PM

> ([datetime]'01-01-2018 00:00:00Z').ToLocalTime()

Sunday, December 31, 2017 4:00:00 PM

> ([datetime]'01-01-2018 00:00:00Z').AddSeconds(15638400)

Saturday, June 30, 2018 4:00:00 PM

> ([datetime]'01-01-2018 00:00:00Z').AddSeconds(15638400).ToLocalTime()

Saturday, June 30, 2018 4:00:00 PM

```

In any event, the actual semantics of `System.DateTime` are determined by .NET -- we can't really fix them.
But there's not great documentation of this stuff in the .NET docs. May with worth opening an issue with them.
